sure.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: confident that you know something or that something is true or correct
sure.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: ‘What time does the show start?’ ‘I’m not sure.’
I’m sure there’s a logical explanation for all this.
Are you sure that you know how to get there?
My mother, I felt sure, had not met him before.
Henry wasn’t sure how to answer this.
I’m not sure if I’m pronouncing this correctly.
He wasn’t even sure of his mother’s name.
They were talking about her, she was sure of that.
‘That’s the man I saw in the building last night.’ ‘Are you quite sure (=completely sure) about that?’
sure.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: In writing, people often prefer to use certain rather than sure, because it sounds more formal:
We cannot be certain what causes this phenomenon.
sure.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: certain about what you feel, want, like etc
sure.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Are you sure you really want a divorce?
Carla says she is very sure of her love for Tony.
sure.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: One thing’s for sure, we’ll never be able to move this furniture on our own.
Those black clouds are a sure sign of rain.
sure.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: certain to happen, succeed, or have a particular result
sure thing/bet American English (=something that will definitely happen, win, succeed etc)
sure.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: There was only one sure way of finding out – and that was to visit him.
sure way to do something/of doing something
He’s sure to get nervous and say something stupid.
sure.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: Are you quite sure she won’t mind?
I’m pretty sure it was the same woman who called the office last week.
Don’t throw anything away until you are absolutely sure you won’t need it again.
I’m not exactly sure when the funeral is.
Make a list of any words or phrases whose meaning you are not too sure about.
By now, we were not at all sure where we were.
sure.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: sure
believing that something is definitely true or correct
I’m sure that you’re right.
‘The car was a BMW.’ ‘Are you sure?’
I’m not sure what the best thing to do is.
certain
completely sure. Certain  is more formal than sure, and it is very commonly used in writing
The police were certain that they had found the killer.
I think he’s married, but I’m not certain about it.
convinced
sure that something is true, even though you cannot prove it
She became convinced that her boyfriend was seeing someone else.
Brown’s wife was convinced of his innocence.
completely sure that something is true, especially when other people are not sure
She said she was positive that the exam was next Tuesday.
I’m absolutely positive I haven’t made a mistake.
satisfied
sure that you know the truth about something that has happened, because you have enough information
The authorities are now satisfied that her death was an accident.
confident
sure that something good will happen or that you will achieve something
Doctors are confident that he’ll make a full recovery.
A spokesman said the government was confident of winning the vote.
have no doubt
to have no doubts in your mind about something
I have no doubt that his story is true.
He was in no doubt about what he should do next.
know
to have a strong feeling that something is true or correct
I just know that she will love this necklace.
When the phone rang, we knew something terrible must have happened.
sure.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: ‘Can you give me a ride to work tomorrow?’ ‘Sure.’
sure.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: used as a reply when you accept thanks from someone
sure.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: It sure is hot out here.
I sure hope they get there all right.
sure.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: used at the beginning of a statement admitting that something is true, especially before adding something very different
sure.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: Sure Joey’s happy now, but will it last?
